docs.title: Home
docs.text:
doesn't work

Table of Contents 01 Introduction and Best Practices 02 Subject Scene Context 03 Camera Grammar 04 Model Position 05 Lighting Guide 06 Lens Optics Depth 07 Exposure Color Pipeline 08 Visual Styles Genres 09 Editorial Screen Grammar 10 Environment Atmosphere Physics 11 Audio in Prompts 12 Output Quality Modifiers 13 Platform Guidelines 14 Synonyms and Templates 15 Prompting Strategy Checklist

docs.title: Main takeaway
docs.text: Use precise, production-grade terminology to describe a single scene with clear subject, action, scene context, camera grammar, lighting, lens intent, and style. Favor direct, positive phrasing and anchor prompts in industry terms that engines like Google Veo/Imagen and Runway recognize. For image-to-video, describe motion only.

docs.title: Platform-aligned best practices
docs.text:
• Be explicit and concise; avoid conversational hedging. Prefer “Low-angle close-up, dim low-key lighting” to vague descriptions.
  • Use positive phrasing; describe what to include (avoid “no/without”).
  • Focus on one moment per prompt; create separate clips for multi-beat stories.
  • Image-to-video: describe camera motion, subject motion, and environmental motion only; do not re-describe visuals present in the source image.
  • Dialogue formatting (video): Character says: Hello there. Avoid quotation marks to reduce subtitle rendering.
  • Use aspect ratios explicitly per output: 16:9, 9:16, 1:1.

docs.title: Subject types
docs.text:
• People by role or archetype (e.g., stoic knight, weary detective), age, wardrobe, era
  • Animals (breed specificity), mythical/fantastical
  • Objects (hero prop, vehicle type, device), abstract forms
  • Multiple subjects (ensemble blocking; interactions; spatial relationships)

docs.title: Actions and beats
docs.text:
• Basic movement: walking, running, turning, looking, rising, collapsing
  • Interactions: conversing, arguing, embracing, handing over, revealing
  • Expressions: confident, uneasy, devastated, resolute
  • Subtle cues: hair ruffles, swallow, micro-smile, blinking
  • Transformations/process: blooming, melting, construction montage, decay

docs.title: Scene and context
docs.text:
• Interior/exterior, time of day (dawn, golden hour, blue hour, night), weather (overcast, drizzle, thunderstorm, fog, snow)
  • Locale: cyberpunk alley, medieval courtyard, sterile lab, desert plateau
  • Atmospherics: dust motes in beams, wet street reflections, heat haze, floating pollen
  • Era/world: 1920s jazz club, 1980s arcade, near-future lab, alien desert

docs.title: Angles
docs.text:
• Eye-level (neutral), High-angle (dominance reduction), Low-angle (power), Worm’s-eye (extreme low)
  • Bird’s-eye / Overhead / Top-down (map-like), Aerial/Drone
  • Dutch / Canted / Oblique angle (tilted horizon; disorientation)
  • Over-the-shoulder (OTS), Point-of-view (POV)

docs.title: Shot sizes
docs.text:
• Extreme wide (XWS), Wide/Long (WS/LS), Full shot
  • Medium (MS), Medium close-up (MCU), Close-up (CU), Extreme close-up (ECU)
  • Two-shot, Three-shot, Group shot
  • Establishing / Re-establishing

docs.title: Fundamental
docs.text:
• Static/fixed
  • Pan (L/R), Tilt (U/D), Roll
  • Dolly (in/out), Truck/Track (left/right), Pedestal (up/down)
  • Zoom (lens focal change; distinct from dolly)

docs.title: Advanced
docs.text:
• Arc shot (circular move), Crane/Jib (vertical sweeps, reveals)
  • Tracking/follow shot (subject-aligned movement)
  • Whip pan (rapid, blurred transition), Push-in, Pull-out
  • Handheld/shaky cam (documentary feel), Steadicam (stabilized float)

docs.title: Structure and guidance
docs.text:
• Rule of thirds; Centered/symmetry; Balance/asymmetry
  • Leading lines; Frame-in-frame; Negative space
  • Layering: Foreground/Middleground/Background; deep space
  • Headroom; Noseroom/Lead room; Horizon placement
  • Blocking and staging (crosses, silhouette read, clean contours)

docs.title: I. Model's Orientation
docs.text:
These terms describe how the model positions their face and body relative to the lens (horizontally).

English Term Polish Translation (Reference) Description Head-on / Straight-on / Full-frontal Na wprost / Cały przód The model's face and entire body are directed straight into the lens. Three-quarter angle / Three-quarter view / Three-quarter profile Trzy czwarte (3/4) / Półprofil The model is turned about 45 degrees away from the camera. A very popular and flattering angle, often slimming and revealing facial features effectively. Two-thirds angle / Two-thirds view Półprofil A position where the model is turned slightly more than a three-quarter view, but not fully in profile. Profile / Full profile Profil The model is turned completely sideways to the camera (90 degrees). Only one side of the face and the body outline are visible. Used to emphasize the jawline or silhouette. Three-quarter rear view Pół tyłem The model is turned away from the camera, but with a slight twist, so that the back of the body and a small portion of the profile are visible.

docs.title: II. Vertical Camera Angle
docs.text:
These terms describe the height of the camera in relation to the model.

English Term Polish Translation (Reference) Description Eye-level shot / Eye-level angle Na poziomie wzroku The camera is at the same height as the model's eyes. This is a neutral, natural angle that creates a sense of equality and closeness. High angle shot / Down shot Z góry The camera is positioned higher than the model and aimed downwards. Can make the model look smaller, more vulnerable, or less dominant. Low angle shot Z dołu The camera is positioned lower than the model and aimed upwards. Makes the model appear taller, more dominant, strong, or monumental.

docs.title: Core lights
docs.text:
• Key light (main/primary), Fill light (shadow control), Backlight (rim/edge/hair; separation)
  • Kicker light (side-back edge; comparable to kontra)
  • Practical (visible fixtures: lamp, TV, neon), Motivated (logical source imitation)
  • Ambient/available/natural light

docs.title: Geometry and quality
docs.text:
• Direction: top light, underlight, sidelight, cross-light
  • Quality: hard (specular, sharp shadows) vs soft (diffuse, wrap)
  • Bounce light, diffusion, cookies/gobos, gels

docs.title: Cinematic modes
docs.text:
• High-key (bright, low-contrast), Low-key (moody, high-contrast)
  • Chiaroscuro; Rembrandt; Split; Loop; Butterfly/Paramount
  • Silhouette/backlit; Volumetric light/god rays
  • Golden hour glow; Blue hour ambience; Neon/fluorescent/tungsten ambiance

docs.title: Lens intent
docs.text:
• Wide-angle (e.g., 18/24/35mm; expansive, perspective exaggeration)
  • Standard/Normal (50mm; natural perspective)
  • Telephoto (85/135/200mm; compression, isolation)
  • Macro (extreme detail), Fisheye (extreme barrel distortion)
  • Anamorphic look (oval bokeh, horizontal flares, widescreen aspect)

docs.title: Focus and depth
docs.text:
• Shallow depth of field; Deep focus; Selective focus; Rack focus; Focus pull
  • Bokeh character (creamy, swirly, specular discs)
  • Hyperfocal emphasis; Plane of focus language

docs.title: Optical effects
docs.text:
• Lens flare, Ghosting, Chromatic aberration, Halation, Bloom
  • Vertigo effect/Dolly zoom (size constant, background warps)

docs.title: Exposure triangle
docs.text:
• Aperture (f-stops), Shutter speed/angle, ISO
  • Metering (spot/center-weighted/matrix), Histogram
  • ETTR/ETTL, Bracketing, HDR

docs.title: Motion and time
docs.text:
• Long exposure (light trails, motion blur), High-speed (slow motion), Under/overcrank
  • Time-lapse, Hyperlapse

docs.title: Color science and balance
docs.text:
• White balance (Kelvin), Tint
  • Color temperature: warm/cool; sodium vapor; fluorescent green; LED blue; neon magenta

docs.title: Image qualities
docs.text:
• Sharpness/acutance, Microcontrast
  • Tonal separation, Midtone contrast, Highlight roll-off, Shadow detail
  • Noise/grain (analog texture), Compression artifacts

docs.title: Cinematic looks
docs.text:
• Photorealistic/ultra-realistic; Cinematic film look; 35mm/65mm film
  • Anamorphic widescreen; Editorial/fashion; Documentary/naturalistic; Film noir

docs.title: Grading and palettes
docs.text:
• Teal & orange; Warm golden; Cool cyan/steel; Pastel/muted; Sepia; Monochrome/B&W
  • High-contrast/punchy; Low-contrast/soft; Bleach-bypass feel

docs.title: Textural and analog
docs.text:
• Film grain; Halation; Bloom; Glow; Vignette; Light leaks; Gate weave (subtle)
  • CRT scanlines; VHS noise (if stylistically relevant)

docs.title: Animation and art references
docs.text:
• Anime; Classic Disney; Pixar-like 3D; Stop-motion/Claymation; Cel-shaded
  • Movements: Impressionist, Surrealist, Art Deco, Bauhaus

docs.title: Genre mood tags
docs.text: • Suspenseful/tense; Peaceful/serene; Epic/grand; Romantic/intimate; Melancholic/poignant; Whimsical

docs.title: Cutting concepts
docs.text:
• Hard cut; Smash cut; Jump cut; Match cut; Match on action
  • Shot/reverse-shot; Eyeline match; Cut-in; Cutaway
  • L-cut; J-cut; Crosscutting/Intercut; Montage (time compression)

docs.title: Continuity rules
docs.text:
• 180-degree rule; 30-degree rule; Axis of action
  • Re-establishing shot; Insert/Detail; Reaction shot
  • Split diopter (both foreground and background in focus)

docs.title: On-screen text and graphics
docs.text: • Super/Superimpose; Chyron; Lower third

docs.title: Location and time
docs.text:
• INT/EXT; DAY/NIGHT; Twilight, Golden hour, Blue hour
  • Urban street/neon-lit alley; Rural pasture; Natural setting; Industrial site

docs.title: Weather and air
docs.text:
• Overcast softbox sky; Rain streaks; Wet asphalt reflections; Snowfall; Fog/mist/haze; Dust/sand
  • Volumetrics: light shafts, god rays; Particulates

docs.title: Motion physics
docs.text:
• Wind: hair/clothes/leaves; Water: dripping/splashing/ripples; Fire: flicker/embers
  • Gravity cues; Camera motion blur; Parallax and occlusion for depth

docs.title: Sound design
docs.text:
• Sound effects: phone ring, door creak, footsteps on wet pavement
  • Ambience: city hum, ocean surf, forest insects
  • Dialogue: Character says: Keep moving. (no quotes to avoid subtitles)
  • Music: subtle underscore; swelling strings; synth pulse

docs.title: Quality and resolution
docs.text:
• High-resolution; Ultra-detailed; 8K-quality render; Studio-quality; Clean render
  • Sharp focus; Soft focus; Selective focus; Clean ISO; Natural grain

docs.title: Aspect ratio and format
docs.text:
• 16:9 (landscape), 9:16 (vertical), 1:1 (square)
  • Safe framing for multi-platform deliverables

docs.title: Google Veo/Imagen and Runway Recommendations
docs.text:
• Structure (Veo-style): Subject + Action + Scene + Camera angle + Camera movement + Lens/DOF + Lighting + Style/Mood + Audio
  • Single scene per prompt; sequence multi-beat stories as separate clips
  • Image-to-video: prompt for motion only (camera motion, subject animation, environment)
  • Dialogue formatting: Character says: … (avoid quotes)
  • Runway references: visual references handle look/identity; text prompt controls action; avoid re-describing referenced visuals
  • Positive, direct language; avoid negative prompts and redundant restatements

docs.title: Angles and sizes
docs.text:
• Dutch angle → canted angle, oblique angle, tilted horizon
  • Bird’s-eye → top-down, overhead, map view
  • Eye-level → straight-on, neutral angle
  • ECU → extreme close up: detail shot; Tight shot
  • EWS → panoramic shot; ultra-wide

docs.title: Movement
docs.text:
• Dolly in → push-in; move closer
  • Truck → lateral move; side-to-side track
  • Pedestal up → vertical lift; raise camera
  • Handheld → shaky cam; documentary feel
  • Steadicam → stabilized floating move; smooth drift

docs.title: JSON Template for VEO-3
docs.text:
{
  "Subject": "",
  "Action": "",
  "Scene, Context": "",
  "Camera angles": "",
  "Camera movements": "",
  "Lens and Effects": "",
  "Visual style": "",
  "Temporal elements": "",
  "Audio": ""
}

docs.title: Cinematic Still
docs.text: • “Low-angle medium close-up of a weary detective in a rain-soaked neon alley, shallow DOF on 85mm, soft key with subtle kicker for edge separation, moody low-key lighting with teal-orange grade, gentle lens bloom and light haze.”

docs.title: Assembly checklist
docs.text:
• Define one scene and its key beat
  • Lock angle, size, and movement
  • State lens/DOF intent
  • Specify lighting type, quality, and mood
  • Add style/grade and texture cues
  • Include atmospherics or physics as needed
  • For video: add audio line(s) or ambience
  • Confirm aspect ratio(s) and quality modifiers

docs.title: Use Photographic Language
docs.text:
Describe lighting precisely: Specify source, direction, and color temperature, such as “soft morning sunlight from the left” or “warm golden hour lighting”.

Mention camera settings: Add terms like “shot on DSLR, 50mm lens, f/1.8 aperture, 8K resolution, cinematic lighting, HDR” to push for a photorealistic look.

For Nano Banana, request micro-details: “Preserve skin texture, pores and subtle imperfections to add realism, maintain natural proportions, sharpen eyes with natural catchlights, increase micro-contrast and avoid plastic smoothing”.
